metadata.sermon_title: The Word Moses Could Not Say
metadata.preacher: Likely Gardner C. Taylor (based on style and references)
metadata.sermon_start_end: This verse has a missing word! I think of nowhere else in the sixty-six books of the Bible in which there is a word missing and a dash drawn [...] I like to call his name. Sometimes when the world is tossing me like a ship upon the sea, I call that name, 'Jesus,' and he steadies me.
metadata.liturgical_context: Likely a Sunday service in an African American homiletical tradition
metadata.historical_context: Mentions the Golan Heights and Sinai (post-1967 context) and the 'martyred prince' Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (post-1968).
metadata.notes: The sermon utilizes the 'aposiopesis' (the silence/dash in the Hebrew text of Exodus 32:32) as its central aesthetic and theological pivot.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon excels in creating a 'cinematic' experience, as advocated by Paul Scott Wilson. It avoids abstract definitions of sin and idolatry, instead painting a vivid scene of the 'golden calf glistening in the desert sun.' The preacher uses sensory details—the 'stench' of the situation is implied through the 'shrill and frantic shouts' and the 'whirling in sensuous circles.' The imagery of the 'hiding tenant and searching Landlord' in Eden provides a fresh, domestic metaphor for the cosmic fall. The use of 'brand out of the fire' and 'miry clay' anchors the sermon in biblical topography while making it visually accessible to the hearer. It successfully 'shows' the frenzy of the valley versus the solitude of the mountain.
quotes: The golden calf glistened in the desert sun... it was bright and shining, it could be touched.
God's own people whirling in sensuous circles, working themselves into frenzy by quick motions and shrill and frantic shouts.
A hiding tenant and a searching Landlord crying, 'Adam, where art thou?'
strengths: Strong use of contrast between the 'mountain solitude' and the 'reveling crowd' in the valley.
Tactile language: 'touchable by these hands,' 'natural finger,' 'leper's spots.'
Effective 'painting' of the biblical narrative to make the ancient text feel contemporary.
improvement_points: Some metaphors like 'ship upon the sea' are slightly conventional; more original maritime imagery could enhance the ending.
The transition to the 'ghetto areas' could be more visually grounded in specific imagery rather than just the term 'ghetto.'
The 'serum for the dread disease' metaphor is strong but could be expanded to be more sensory.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly 'show' oriented. The preacher describes the scene so vividly that the theological 'telling' feels like a natural conclusion to the visual experience.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is dignified and precise, reflecting Marilyn Chandler McEntyre’s 'stewardship of language.' The preacher avoids modern slang, opting for a 'high' style that fits the gravity of the subject. The term 'aposiopesis' (though not named) is handled with precision through the image of the 'dash' and the 'blank.' There is a clear intentionality in word choice, such as 'skittish,' 'capitulated,' and 'confluence.' However, there is a slight tendency toward rhetorical flourish ('mammoth events and vast and weighty considerations') which occasionally borders on the pleonastic, though it serves the oral rhythm well.
quotes: A great confluence, a mighty coming together of mammoth events and vast and weighty considerations.
People are saved not by being flattered but by being faced and, in love, being opposed.
The embryo nation so strong as the one against idols, manmade gods.
strengths: Excellent use of alliteration and balanced clauses ('flattered' vs 'faced').
Avoidance of 'Canaanite' jargon; theological terms like 'idolatry' are defined through human behavior.
Precise naming of the 'missing word' as a structural device.
improvement_points: Reduction of redundant adjectives (e.g., 'mammoth,' 'vast,' and 'weighty' in one sentence).
The reference to 'Moses Maimonides' might be too academic for some audiences without a brief explanation of who he was.
Clarify the 'diplomat' simile to ensure it doesn't feel too detached from the desert context.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Theological jargon is minimal. When used (e.g., 'commonwealth of faith'), it is contextualized by the surrounding narrative of community and loyalty.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest aesthetic strength. It is clearly composed for the ear, not the eye, embodying Gerrit Immink's 'performance' aspect. The rhythm is homiletically 'black' in its cadence—using repetition ('Look at them!', 'Shame!'), parallelism, and varying sentence lengths to build tension. The 'staccato' of the shame-sequence contrasts beautifully with the 'legato' of the final Christological section. The use of the hymn at the end provides a rhythmic and melodic resolution that satisfies the 'musical' expectation of the genre. The cadence of 'I know a name...' creates a powerful rhetorical crescendo.
quotes: Look at them! God's people disgracing themselves... Look at them! God's own people whirling in sensuous circles.
I know a name that can change the leper's spots and melt a heart of stone. I know a name that can set cold lands on fire.
Lord, if thou will not forget their sin, blot me out of the book which thou has written.
strengths: Masterful use of anaphora ('I know a name...') to build emotional intensity.
Excellent rhythmic variation between long, descriptive sentences and short, punchy exclamations.
The sermon has a 'pulse' that mirrors the heartbeat of the narrative's tension.
improvement_points: The transition from the historical Moses to the contemporary application could have a slightly smoother rhythmic bridge.
Ensure the 'Shame!' repetitions don't become monotonous if not delivered with varying inflection.
The quote from Dr. Horton is a bit 'clunky' compared to the poetic flow of the rest of the text.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Pure oral language. The text breathes and demands to be spoken aloud.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The sermon demonstrates a high level of micro-aesthetic mastery. It utilizes vivid, sensory imagery to 're-frame' (Cilliers) the ancient Sinai narrative for a modern audience. The language is both precise and highly musical, avoiding the dryness of 'paper language.' By focusing on the 'missing word' (the dash), the preacher creates a linguistic void that the rest of the sermon rhythmically fills. The imagery is not merely decorative but serves as the primary vehicle for the theological movement from law to grace.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a classic 'Lowry Loop' or narrative plot. It begins with an 'upsetting of the equilibrium'—the missing word/the dash. This creates immediate curiosity. The movement goes from the mountain (revelation) to the valley (crisis/sin) and back to the mountain (intercession). The 'turning point' is Moses' willingness to be 'blotted out,' which then pivots to the ultimate resolution: the name of Jesus. The tension is sustained by the 'blank' in the text, which is only fully filled in the final moments. It is a dynamic journey from the silence of the Law to the speech of the Gospel.
quotes: This verse has a missing word! ... a dash drawn to show that some unknown word or words ought to be where now this blank occurs.
Hurriedly, like a diplomat moving speedily... Moses rushes down the mountain.
Moses says, 'If thou wilt forgive them,' but now we see a blank. I thank God we can fill the blank.
strengths: The 'missing word' serves as a brilliant 'hook' that sustains interest throughout.
Clear movement from 'Trouble' (the calf) to 'Grace' (the Name), following Paul Scott Wilson's Four Pages.
The conclusion provides a satisfying 'catharsis' by finally naming the silence.
improvement_points: The middle section regarding leadership and flattery, while good, slightly slows the narrative momentum of the Sinai story.
The transition from Moses' intercession to the 'heart and essence' could be more seamless.
The historical references to the Golan Heights feel slightly dated and could be more universally integrated into the 'desert' theme.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey. It is not a three-point lecture but a narrative exploration of a textual 'wound' (the dash).

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: The sermon performs 'reframing' (Cilliers) by connecting the 'golden calf' to modern 'worldly ambition' and 'earthly pleasure.' The integration of the Civil Rights movement (Dr. King) and the 'ghetto areas' provides a powerful contextual anchor, making the 'public interest' vs 'greed' a modern Sinai. However, the connection between the 'Golan Heights' and the biblical text is more of a geographical footnote than a deep theological integration. The 'reframing' of the dash as the 'space for Jesus' is a creative synthesis that respects the 'strangeness' of the Hebrew text while making it relevant.
quotes: How programs in our ghetto areas cry out for people who will put the lifting of their brothers and sisters above their own greed.
I will ask: How many have been the occasions... when you and I have found something else dearer to us than Jesus Christ?
The most recent scenes of which are being enacted even now in the hot desert of Sinai and in the Golan Heights.
strengths: Effective use of 'reframing' sin as 'trusting in what can be seen.'
Strong ethical application regarding leadership and sacrifice (King reference).
The biblical 'then' and the congregational 'now' are in constant dialogue.
improvement_points: The mention of the 'Golan Heights' feels a bit like a 'period piece' and could be updated or deepened.
The 'hiding tenant/searching landlord' metaphor is excellent but could be more explicitly linked to the 'ghetto' context mentioned later.
Ensure the 'new Israel' concept is handled with care to avoid simple supersessionism.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes. It reframes the silence of the Law as the 'waiting room' for the Gospel.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: In terms of Ciska Stark's 'Open Work of Art,' the sermon is somewhat monovalent. It drives toward a single, powerful answer: Jesus. While it acknowledges the 'ambivalence of existence' through the description of sin and the 'missing word,' the resolution is quite 'sealed.' The 'blank' is filled definitively. However, it leaves room for the hearer's own 'shame' and 'sinking' to be brought into the story. It is 'open' in its invitation to call the Name, but 'closed' in its dogmatic certainty. The 'mystery' of the dash is explained away by the end, which provides comfort but reduces the 'polyvalence' of the silence.
quotes: I know the missing word. It is 'Jesus'.
I will not stop to inquire if this depraved and debased condition... On second thought, I will ask.
Moses lived too early, though he sensed there must be some such way.
strengths: The preacher invites the hearer into the 'blank' of the text.
The use of rhetorical questions allows the hearer to self-examine.
The ending is an invitation to 'call the name,' which is an open-ended spiritual practice.
improvement_points: Allow the 'silence' of Moses to linger a bit longer before providing the 'answer.'
Acknowledge that for some, the 'blank' remains a place of struggle even after hearing the Name.
Avoid making the 'missing word' feel like a riddle with a simple one-word answer.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Primarily monovalent. It is a 'closed' work in the sense that it provides a specific, singular key to the text's mystery.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic structure is robust, driven by a compelling narrative arc that utilizes a textual anomaly (the dash) as its engine. It moves effectively between the 'trouble' of the human condition and the 'grace' of the divine response. While the 'reframing' of the Sinai event into the Civil Rights context is powerful, the sermon's structure is quite traditional in its movement toward a closed Christological resolution. It functions as a 'witness' (Long) to the Name that fills the gaps of human failure.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon largely avoids religious kitsch by taking the 'pain of suffering' and the 'gravity of sin' seriously. It does not offer a 'happy ending' without first dwelling in the 'shame' and the 'miry clay.' However, the final section's reliance on 'calling the name' could border on sentimentality if not grounded in the preceding 'wrestle' of Moses. The 'ship upon the sea' imagery is a bit clichéd. Yet, the authentic depth of Moses' sacrifice ('blot me out') prevents the sermon from becoming a 'pre-chewed' emotional product. It sustains the tension of justice and mercy for a significant duration.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'ship upon the sea' metaphor is a standard homiletical cliché.
The phrase 'set cold lands on fire' is somewhat 'stained-glass' language.
authentic_moments: The raw description of the 'sensuous circles' and the 'shame' of the people.
The profound theological question: 'How can justice and mercy shake hands with each other?'
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: To further avoid kitsch, deepen the 'ghetto' application with more concrete, un-beautified reality before moving to the 'Jesus' resolution.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: The sermon successfully creates a 'Space for Grace' (Cilliers) by highlighting the inadequacy of the Law and the 'blank' that only God can fill. It does not close the space with moralism (though it has strong ethical demands); rather, it shows that even the greatest 'Lawgiver' reaches a limit where only Grace can speak. The 'mystery' of God's forgiveness is respected as something that Moses 'sensed' but could not fully grasp, leaving the 'vertical' dimension open.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between 'justice' and 'mercy' is the central pivot of the sermon.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The 'dash' in the Bible is treated as a holy mystery, though the preacher is eager to provide the Christological key.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails. The 'must' of the Law is superseded by the 'Name' of the Gospel.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: Ensure the 'Name' is presented not just as a magic word that resolves all problems, but as a presence that dwells within the 'blank' of our lives.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically strong example of the African American 'Prince of Pulpit' tradition (likely Gardner C. Taylor). Its primary aesthetic power lies in its musicality and its narrative 'reframing' of a textual silence. By focusing on the 'dash' in Exodus 32:32, the preacher creates a dramaturgical void that demands a resolution, which is then masterfully delivered through a Christological crescendo. The imagery is vivid and sensory, effectively 'showing' the chaos of the valley and the solemnity of the mountain. While it leans toward a 'closed' structure by providing a singular answer to the text's mystery, the path to that answer is paved with authentic existential struggle and ethical seriousness. The stewardship of language is evident in the rhythmic cadences and the precise, yet poetic, word choices. It avoids the 'kitsch' of easy comfort by first demanding that the hearer 'hang their head' in the shame of the valley.
strengths_top_3: Rhythmic and musical cadence that builds to a powerful emotional and theological climax.
Brilliant use of a textual 'blank' (aposiopesis) as the central dramaturgical device.
Vivid, sensory imagery that makes the ancient Sinai narrative palpable.
improvement_points_top_3: Refresh clichéd metaphors (like the 'ship on the sea') with more original imagery.
Deepen the 'openness' by allowing the silence of the 'blank' to challenge the hearer longer.
Update or more deeply integrate the 1960s-era historical references.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages) and Gerrit Immink (Performance/Event).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Hearers who appreciate a 'grand' rhetorical style, narrative tension, and a clear, Christ-centered resolution.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with an 'open ending' that leaves the 'dash' for the congregation to fill in their own week.
Use more 'earthy' metaphors for grace to balance the 'heavenly' name-calling.
Maintain the excellent rhythmic pulse but vary the 'volume' of the imagery.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an aesthetically compelling 'event' that honors the Reformed focus on the Word while embracing the 'aesthetic turn' through performance and imagery. It is a model of how to use the 'form' of the biblical text (even its punctuation) to determine the 'form' of the sermon. While it risks monovalence, its rhetorical beauty and narrative drive make it a powerful piece of homiletic art.
